I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The lack of well-developed local currency bond markets was one of the causes of the  
1997–1998  Asian  financial  crisis.  At  that  time,  overdependence  on  bank  financing  forced  
borrowers to take on excessive short-term foreign exchange exposure to finance long-term 
projects that could generate only local currency revenue, resulting in mismatches with respect to 
both loan maturity and exchange rates.1 When international confidence in one local currency 
caused a rapid depreciation against the United States (US) dollar, a payment crisis ensued, 
exacerbating a loss in confidence across the region (the “contagion” effect). This led to banking 
and  currency  crises  in  several  countries.  Structural  reforms  have  since  been  implemented  
throughout the region, and most crisis-affected economies have recovered and returned to  
robust  growth.  However,  the  absence  of  alternative  sources2  of  long-term  local  currency 
financing and the region’s lack of  efficient bond markets continue to be a source  of potential 
financial vulnerability. 
 
2.  The  finance  ministers  of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)+33  
established the Asian Bond Markets Initiative (ABMI) in August 2003 to boost development of  
local currency bond markets in order to help mitigate the double mismatch problem and recycle 
Asia’s considerable savings within the region. Currently, the ABMI focal group and four working 
 
groups4 focus on (i) expanding the number and diversifying the makeup of issuers in local 
currency bond markets, and (ii) developing an environment conducive and attractive to bond  
market participants. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported the ABMI since its  
inception, particularly through the provision of technical assistance (TA). The ABMI complements  
 
work done by other regional forums on bond market development, including the Executives’ 
Meeting of East Asia-Pacific Central Banks (EMEAP) and Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation  
(APEC). 5  
 
3.  In May 2007, the ABMI working group on creating new securitized debt instruments 
(working group 1, chaired by the Ministry of Finance, Thailand) asked ADB to undertake a study 
on how securitization markets in the ASEAN+3 region could be further developed and to explore  
the various structures and underlying assets that could be securitized in local currencies. ADB 
Management  approved  the  concept  paper  on  17  July  2007.6  The  design  and  monitoring  
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  A decade after the 1997–1998 financial crisis, Asia has experienced a new financial 
contagion, this time from the US—the crisis in the subprime mortgage market, which has raised

4  The four working groups are  working group 1—New securitized debt instruments (chaired by Thailand); working

the focal group, an apex body that oversees overall ABMI progress. 
5   EMEAP initiatives include enhancing the demand side of bond market development through Asian Bond Fund 1

6   The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 28 May 2008.

2   
borrowing  costs  in  global  credit  markets.  This  makes  clear  that  Asian  economies  remain  
vulnerable to large fluctuations in global capital flows. Efficient capital markets in the region 
would therefore help Asia recycle its vast savings within the region, reduce borrowing costs, and 
provide more financing opportunities. Securitization schemes have the potential to become a  
tool to fund the region’s massive financing needs and provide credit support for the loans of 
small and medium-sized enterprises, long-term residential mortgages, and future cash flows 
such as remittances. 
 
5.  Securitization is a means of credit risk transfer that can support financial development  
and  help  bridge  the  gap  between  prevailing  ASEAN+3  credit  quality  and  investor  risk  
preferences. The process usually uses pooled assets or income (including future cash flows),  
configured to provide a  yield that investors find attractive over extended periods. This can help 
more Asian issuers obtain better credit ratings and expand their financing options. Securitization 
would therefore widen the pool of issuers and diversify the existing bond products, for issuers 
and investors, available in the region’s financial markets. 
 
6.  In the US and Europe, securitization is a well-developed technique that has contributed  
to the expansion of debt markets (subject to discussion in para. 9 below) and attracted investors 
from around the world. Despite the growth of the ASEAN+3 securitization market since the 
1997–1998 financial crisis,7 the use of securitization in the region remains modest and its capital  
markets are generally slow to tap its benefits.8  
 
7.  Unlike  in  the  US  and  Europe,  the  financial  infrastructure  in  ASEAN+3  is  currently 
inadequate for securitization. For example, the lack of regulatory framework in these countries  
adds to the cost and effort of securitization. Data collection is insufficient and makes monitoring 
of assets difficult. Transaction costs9 are also relatively high because each transaction is unique 
and the securitization process is relatively non-standardized. This means that services specific 
to the transaction, such as documentation and legal costs, tend to be high. In addition, new  
securitization applications (e.g., microfinance), lacking history, may be difficult to structure and  
distribute. As a result, there is no incentive for corporate players and intermediaries to consider  
securitization as an alternative form of financing. The benefits of securitization are nonetheless 
well documented and acknowledged (footnote 7): it is therefore imperative to explore innovative  
ways to improve structures to achieve higher ratings and lower costs for the borrower.  
 
8.  Because  of  the  availability  in  different  countries  of  various  types  of  assets  for 
securitization,  one  of  the  biggest  challenges  for  securitization  lies  in  developing  legal  and 
regulatory  frameworks.  Globally,  securitization  laws  have  been  changing  to  facilitate 
securitization.  In  the  ASEAN+3  region,  several  common  issues  need  to  be  addressed: 
(i) uncertainty in accounting treatment; (ii) bankruptcy law, especially relating to bankruptcy 
remoteness in various jurisdictions; and (iii) insufficient data on underlying assets. These result 
in  inefficient,  illiquid  markets  and  high  funding  costs.  It  is  therefore  crucial  that  ASEAN+3  
members work collectively toward finding common solutions10 to these and related issues. One  
issue would be the promotion of cross-border  securitization transactions. Region-wide best 
practice guidelines in securitization for the ASEAN+3 countries should also be developed.11

9.  Recent events such as the subprime mortgage crisis in 2007 have affected financial 
markets, particularly in Europe and North America. Although the direct consequences of the  
crisis on the region may be limited, analysts predict that the immediate and long-term effects of 
the shock in the context of securitized instruments may include the following: (i) a change in  
transaction costs resulting from higher regulatory capital or changes in structure, particularly 
transaction warehousing; (ii) a more conservative phase of deal formation and regulation; (iii) a  
long-term  change  in  the  regulatory  setting  covering  accounting  and  capital  requirements;  
(iv) modifications in rating agencies’ involvement in structured finance;12 and (v) changes in the 
responsibilities of originators, intermediaries, and investors in dealing with moral hazard. The  
impact of these changes would therefore be of concern in developing Asia’s securitization  
market. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL  ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA aims to develop the domestic and regional bond markets in the ASEAN+3  
region. The expected outcome is for ASEAN+3  officials to make informed decisions based on  
concrete  and  feasible  policy  recommendations  to  promote  domestic  and  cross-border 
investments in securitized transactions. The TA will cover the ASEAN+3 countries, focusing on  
People’s Republic of China, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam.13   
 
11.  The TA supports ADB’s Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) and the regional  
cooperation and integration strategy, particularly pillar 3 (monetary and financial cooperation and 
integration), which encourages the development of regional bond markets to (i) support regional 
financial  cooperation  and  integration  through  increased  cross-border    transactions,  and 
(ii) promote greater financial stability in the region. The study complements activities to promote  
securitization  projects  by  ADB’s  regional  departments  and  Private  Sector  Operations 
Department.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  All stages of the study will be done in consultation with market participants through  
meetings and/or conferences and will increase existing dialogue with other stakeholders and  
policy makers. The design will be relatively flexible to accommodate views, obtained throughout 
implementation,  from  the  private  sector  and   from  government  officials.  ADB  and  the  TA 
consultants will communicate regularly with  the chair and members of working group 1 to  
discuss  output  and  to  develop  policy  recommendations.  With  preliminary  agreement  from  
working group 1 members, the study will include the following components. 
 
13.  Securitization Market Review and Lessons. The TA will analyze existing securitization  
techniques and identify impediments in the respective markets of the ASEAN+3 countries. It will  
also identify issues common to ASEAN+3 countries and impediments that hinder cross-border 
securitization transactions in the region. Current securitization techniques in the US, Europe,  
                                                                                                                                                           
Securities Best Practice, jointly prepared by the Korean regulators and the private sector; and the American  
Securitization Forum Market Recommended Standards and Practices.

Integration No. 12. Manila: ADB.

and Asia14 and how they may apply to the ASEAN+3 countries will also be analyzed. The study  
will examine the subprime crisis and discuss the impact on the region’s securitization market. It 
will use the findings of recent OREI publications, in particular the April 2007 Asia Bond Monitor 
and the Working Paper Series on Regional Economic Integration No. 12 Securitization in East  
Asia, which included chapters on securitization. Other ADB studies will also be leveraged to 
maximize efficiency and avoid duplication.15  
 
14.  Securitization Scheme(s). The study will suggest innovative schemes that would  help 
generate cross-border issuance/investment and develop the domestic capital markets within the 
ASEAN+3 region. It will discuss the developmental benefits of introducing new underlying assets  
and recommend the various underlying assets16 available for securitization. It will also analyze  
the rationale and benefits of securitization. The study will (i) identify the necessary conditions for  
trading  the  securitized  assets  and  ways  to  enhance  liquidity  in  the  secondary  market;  
(ii) recommend a securitization structure that matches investor demand/risk preferences17 and 
minimizes transaction costs; and (iii) evaluate the risk management issues and financial risk 
exposure of relevant parties and, in particular,  risk mitigation for recent developments such as 
the subprime crisis.18 For underdeveloped markets, a reference sheet19 may be drawn up for the  
country to monitor its progress in developing its capital market for such a scheme.  
 
15.  Case Studies and Best Practice. The study will examine the role of government in the  
development of each country’s securitization market and in cross-border securitization. Based  
on the above analysis and lessons, the study will generate a set of standards, best practices, 
and  policy  recommendations,  including  market  infrastructure  and  conditions,  necessary  to  
promote securitization structures in the ASEAN+3 countries. The study will analyze possible  
standardized schemes, such as master trust transactions backed by assets, originated by multi-
sellers. It will also create a self-assessment template for ASEAN+3 governments to assess each 
country’s progress toward removing impediments, and facilitate the development of efficient 
securitization  markets.  Case  studies  will  be  prepared  to  help  governments  review  their 
respective capital markets development strategies and determine the necessary changes to  
encourage both domestic and cross-border  securitization transactions.

16.  Policy Recommendations. The study will recommend a policy framework to foster a  
favorable environment for the development of cross-border securitization. It will (i) consider the  
government’s role in promoting market and legal harmonization for cross-border securitization  
transactions;  (ii)  explore  cooperation  in  region-wide  credit  rating,  accounting,  and  credit 
guarantee systems; and (iii) examine other ways to enhance the liquidity of issued securitized 
assets. A set of recommendations will be submitted to working group 1 on measures that may 
be adopted by the individual ASEAN+3 countries and regional cooperation efforts that may be  
undertaken to enable securitization and cross-border securitization transactions.  
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at the equivalent of $700,000 which will be financed  
on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The detailed  
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. The ASEAN+3 member countries will  
finance the costs of their individual participation in working group 1 activities. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA,  which  will  be  administered  and 
implemented by OREI in close collaboration with working group 1 member countries, particularly 
Thailand (the working group 1 chair). ADB will supervise the work of the TA consultants. 
 
19.  Three international consultants (a financial market specialist, a structured finance legal 
and regulatory specialist, and a securitization specialist) and one national consultant (project  
coordinator)  will  be  engaged  for  a  total  of  17  person-months  of  international  consultancy 
services and 12 person-months of national consultancy services. They will be engaged by ADB  
as individual consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as  
amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months; it  is expected to start in July 2008 and end  
in June 2009. A series of market consultations with market players and government officials will  
be held within 5 months of commencement. With these inputs, as well as those from government  
officials,  the  interim  report  will  be  submitted  to  working  group  1  within  6  months.  A  final  
presentation to working group 1 is expected in June 2009. The outline of the final report is in  
Appendix 4. Upon completion, the report will be disseminated within ADB and on appropriate  
websites,20  with  external  publication  of  the  report  subject  to  approval  by  working  group  1  
members.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the  
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis for  
Developing Securitization Markets in ASEAN+3 Region, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Financial Market Specialist—Team Leader (5 person-months) 
1.  The  team  leader  will  have  extensive  experience  in  international  financial  markets, 
particularly the structuring aspects of financial products. He/she will supervise and review the  
work of other international consultants and take charge of consolidating their reports into a final  
report. The team leader will leverage existing studies to the extent possible. The team leader, in 
consultation with other experts, will do the following: 
 
(i)  Provide an analysis of the impact and demand of the securitization markets in the 
Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)  +31   region,  focusing  on 
People’s  Republic  of  China,  Indonesia,  Malaysia,  Philippines,  Thailand,  and 
Viet Nam. In addition, a review of the overall securitization market in selected  
ASEAN+3  countries  should  be  covered.  The  review  should  examine  the 
prevailing market conditions for securitization and identify impediments that limit 
the  development  of  securitization,  for  both  domestic  and  cross-border 
securitization.  
(ii)  Analyze the roles of issuers, investors, market participants, and intermediaries in  
the selected ASEAN+3 markets. Examine the existing underlying assets and 
securitization schemes currently available in the region.  
(iii)  Evaluate more advanced securitization markets such as the United States and 
Europe, as well as markets in Asia such as Japan, Republic of Korea, and  
Singapore. Based on the assessment, identify impediments that these markets 
faced in securitization and how it may apply to ASEAN+3 countries. Identify the 
necessary government policy and framework that promotes the development of  
securitization in these markets.  
(iv)  With  the  assistance  of  the  team,  conduct  market  consultations  and  policy

cooperation, and list existing/potential underlying assets for securitization.  
(v)  With  the  assistance  of  the  team  consultants,  recommend  a  securitization  
scheme(s) after identifying potential assets. Identify the rational and benefits of  
securitization for the region.

from the assessment of national securitization markets. 
(vii)  Formulate  policy  recommendations  for  developing  securitization  markets,

preparation of a regional action plan to address constraints.

final report.

regulatory conditions. 
(ii)  Analyze subprime issues and discuss how recent developments will affect Asia 
and the securitization market overall. Discuss the risk management options in  
such an environment.
